sub_topic: Calculating the effect of changing the concentration of reactants or products on the equilibrium position of a redox reaction
message_1:
What is the effect of increasing the concentration of Fe2+ ions on the equilibrium position of the following redox reaction: 

Fe2+(aq) + MnO4-(aq) + H+(aq) â‡Œ Fe3+(aq) + Mn2+(aq) + H2O(l) 

Assuming all other reactant concentrations and reaction conditions are constant, calculate the change in equilibrium concentration of Fe3+ion when the initial concentration of Fe2+ ions is increased from 0.1M to 0.5M.
message_2:
Increasing the concentration of Fe2+ ions will shift the equilibrium position of the redox reaction to the right, according to Le Chatelier's principle. This is because the system will try to counteract the change by consuming the added Fe2+ ions and producing more Fe3+ ions, Mn2+ ions, and H2O.

To calculate the change in equilibrium concentration of Fe3+ ions, we can use the reaction stoichiometry. Since the stoichiometry of the reaction is 1:1 for Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions, the change in the concentration of Fe2+ ions will be equal to the change in the concentration of Fe3+ ions.

Initial concentration of Fe2+ ions = 0.1 M
Final concentration of Fe2+ ions = 0.5 M

Change in concentration of Fe2+ ions = Final concentration - Initial concentration = 0.5 M - 0.1 M = 0.4 M

Since the stoichiometry of the reaction is 1:1 for Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions, the change in the concentration of Fe3+ ions will also be 0.4 M.
